1. A 42-year-old male with a history of thoracic spinal cord injury following a motor vehicle accident presents with worsening constipation and abdominal discomfort over the past six months. He reports increased difficulty with bowel movements, requiring manual disimpaction on several occasions. His symptoms include a sensation of incomplete evacuation and episodes of fecal incontinence, particularly when he has a sudden increase in intra-abdominal pressure. He denies any recent changes in diet or fluid intake. On examination, there is decreased anal sphincter tone and diminished perianal sensation. He uses a wheelchair and has previously managed his bowels with a digital stimulation routine and suppositories. The patient is concerned about the impact of his bowel symptoms on his quality of life and is seeking advice on optimizing his management. Neurogenic bowel secondary to his spinal cord injury is suspected.
